title: How to come up with a good plot for a story - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the asking. Coming up with a good plot these days is dam difficult, because many of the ideas have already been done to death, and the techniques that govern success have also been done to death. If you look at the massivly succesful film series of the lasty 40 years such as Star Wars, Harry Potter, and others then you’ll see that they have some glaring similarities.  The under-dog youngster, the Wizard and the magic sword. LOTR started the ideas flowing and sooo many authors since have copied the basic style and in some cases the whole thing. Don’t get me wrong, I liked Harry Potter immensly, as do my children, but it is a pretty close match for LOTR, on many levels. The link below does have some NSFW publicity on it, beware, but is a very good comparison, too long to post entirely here. 27 Weird Similarities Between Harry Potter And Lord Of The Rings It is not exactly cheating, but as you get older, you start seeing the pattern, and you know what is coming, every single time. So, how do you sell an idea that is different? You do it quickly. I have waited way too long to put my ideas on paper, and as such if I did, people would say that I have copied the ideas of others. I thought about cloaking technology when I was 11 years old, 1976. “Wouldn’t it be a great idea to put a camera behind the television, filming the wall, and then viewing that onscreen, you could make the television almost dissapear.” Anyway. How to find an original and different idea for a story plot? I write down my dreams, as sometimes, my sub concious makes up some real doozies. If you want to be different from the mainstream rules then it has to be really different. I write now, by deliberately comparing my ideas against the ideas already written by others, and then changing for the opposites, where my work is concerned, if the hero is a young lad setting out on an adventure with a wizard, then I’ll make him an old lad coming back from an adventure with an idiot in tow. I write (bad) comedy and sci-fi, I mix them. The problem here is that I should have published years ago, because Farscape, for example, destroyed any chance I have of publishing what I wrote 25 years ago, it is just too similar. “The displaced happy go lucky pilot having an adventure with aliens and comic effect”. You are going to have to look at your idea and ask yourself if it is realistic enough, then you’ll have to run it through the “unreal fantasy mill check”, where you confirm or not if it is at all credible. What limits the size of dragons in films? The visual credibility, if it is a dragon the size of a planet attacking earth, it doesn’t really work, so you get Godzilla as a kind of maximum acceptable size. If you are going to write a character’s style, then he/she/it has to be ‘credible’, otherwise people are going to read it and say “nah”. How on earth do we do that? By observing what the audience will accept, and pushing the boundaries. One of the best and most surprising “new” plot styles, (it’s not new, just refreshed) was the recent Deadpool movie, that broke the 4th wall and allowed the character to interact directly with us the audience. It works very well, and I for one have written story lines using that premise. (years ago… should have published, man, am I kicking myself now) You’re lucky these days that we have the internet, because what ever you write, you can publish it on the net. This gives you a far better way of having your work analysed for free, instead of not getting past the publishers trash basket. Work to a plan, and “tweek” it just enough that it isn’t a copy of others work, or throw lines into a bucket and pull out randomly, in much the same way that David Bowie once wrote his songs. The one thing that you will come up against is that “there are no new ideas”, it’s all been done. But as Harry Potter, Star Wars, and others prove, it can be redone again and again. Just slightly different each time. If JK Rowling tells us that she hasn’t read LOTR, she’s fibbing.  The main way to come up with ideas and plot lines is to brainstorm with other writers and artists, spend nights eating and drinking together until something useful takes shape, that’s how I grew my ideas sometimes. I think that no matter what you think of your work, you should publish it somewhere, and as such should take heed of my own advice.
